questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

 

The utricle and saccule are part of the vestibular system in the inner ear, which is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and orientation. They do not participate in the hearing process but are involved in sensing linear accelerations.

 

  • Utricle: Senses horizontal linear movements.
  • Saccule: Senses vertical linear movements.

 

Both structures contain sensory epithelia known as the maculae, which house hair cells that respond to shifts in movement through the displacement of tiny stones called otoliths on a gel-like layer.

 

Semicircular canals sense the Angular movements.

 

Hearing is sensed by Organ of Corti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hearing high frequency sounds & C. Hearing low frequency sounds: These functions are attributed to the cochlea, where sound vibrations are converted into nerve signals that are interpreted by the brain. High and low frequency sound detection is facilitated by different regions of the cochlear basilar membrane.

 

Option D. Angular acceleration: This is the specific function of the semicircular canals, which are filled with fluid and contain sensory hair cells that respond to the rotation of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 6-year-old male who presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk operation

 

The 6-year-old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue, which is characteristic of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This cyst forms from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which usually obliterates as the thyroid gland descends from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue to its final position in the neck. When part of this duct remains patent, it can form a cyst.

 

The appropriate treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst is the Sistrunk operation. This surgical procedure involves removing the cyst along with the central portion of the hyoid bone and a tract leading to the base of the tongue to ensure complete excision and reduce the risk of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemithyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves removing one lobe of the thyroid gland, which is not necessary for treating a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option C. Total thyroidectomy: This is incorrect because removing the entire thyroid gland is not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option D. Subtotal thyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves partial removal of the thyroid gland, which is also not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk operation is the treatment of choice for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the removal of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the tract to the base of the tongue.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kroner’s procedure

 

Explanation:

 

Fimbriectomy is a method of tubal ligation where the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. This technique is also known as Kroner’s procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy technique: In this method, the mid-isthmic portion of the Fallopian tube is elevated and then folded at the midpoint. One or two rapidly absorbable sutures are tied around the double thickness of the tube, and the folded portion is excised sharply.

 

Option B. Uchida's procedure: This involves ligating and excising the midportion of the Fallopian tube. The utero-tubal serosa is then hydro-dissected, and the proximal tubal stump is pulled into the mesosalpinx. The peritoneum is closed over the proximal cut end of the tube.

 

Option D. Irving's procedure: In this method, the midportion of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. The proximal tubal stump is inserted into an incision made into the myometrium and securely sutured to bury the proximal stump in the myometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriectomy, also known as Kroner's procedure, involves ligation and excision of the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the image and make the diagnosis (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichobezoar

 

The image shows a trichobezoar, which is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract, usually due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) associated with the psychiatric condition trichotillomania.

 

In trichotillomania, individuals have an irresistible urge to pull out their hair, and sometimes they may also swallow the hair. Over an extended period of time, the ingested hair can accumulate and form a solid mass called a trichobezoar. This hair ball can cause obstruction in the stomach or small intestine, leading to acute abdominal pain that requires surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Splenic rupture is incorrect as the image does not depict a ruptured spleen. A splenic rupture would typically present with intra-abdominal hemorrhage and signs of hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. Pancreatic necrosis is incorrect as the image does not show necrotic pancreatic tissue. Pancreatic necrosis is a severe complication of acute pancreatitis and would not present as a well-defined mass in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Polycystic kidney is incorrect as the image is not depicting the kidneys. Polycystic kidney disease is characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, causing enlargement and progressive loss of renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A trichobezoar is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) in patients with trichotillomania, and can cause acute abdominal pain due to obstruction.

questions.text: A lactating mother who follows a strict vegetarian diet presents with fatigue, weakness, and numbness in her extremities. Upon examination, her blood work reveals a decreased total iron binding capacity. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this clinical picture?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency


The clinical presentation of fatigue, weakness, and numbness in the extremities is indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency, especially in someone following a strict vegetarian diet. Vitamin B12, or cobalamin, is predominantly found in animal products, and those following a vegetarian diet are at higher risk for deficiency.

 

Key symptoms of B12 deficiency include:

 

  • Fatigue and weakness due to megaloblastic anemia.
  • Numbness and tingling in the extremities due to progressive peripheral neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency: Typically presents with fatigue and pallor with elevated TIBC. Numbness is not a common symptom.

 

Option B. Zinc deficiency: Can cause various symptoms including growth retardation and impaired immune function, but does not typically present with anemia and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Folate deficiency: Can also cause megaloblastic anemia but does not usually cause peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency should be considered in individuals with a strict vegetarian diet presenting with symptoms of megaloblastic anemia (fatigue, weakness) and progressive peripheral neuropathy (numbness in extremities).

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

 

The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst, with the characteristic black punctum.

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • The most common locations for sebaceous cysts are the face, neck, chest, and back especially postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.
  • They typically appear as small, painless lumps that are round or oval in shape.
  • Treatment for sebaceous cysts involves surgical removal of the cyst. This is usually done under local anesthesia, and involves making a small elliptical incision in the skin and removing the cyst and its contents.
  • It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign, slow-growing cystic lesion that can occur in various parts of the body, including the head and neck.
  • These cysts are often present from birth (congenital) and can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and sometimes sebaceous (oil-producing) material.
  • Dermoid cysts are typically painless unless they become infected or inflamed.
  • Treatment involves surgical removal to prevent complications or for cosmetic reasons.

 

Option C. Meningioma:

 

  • A meningioma is a typically benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing and may not cause symptoms initially.
  • When symptoms occur, they can include headaches, seizures, changes in vision or hearing, and neurological deficits.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging studies like MRI and CT scans, and treatment may involve surgery or radiation therapy depending on the tumor's location and size.

 

Option D. Postauricular Fistula:

 

  • A postauricular fistula, also known as a auricular sinus or pit, is a small hole or pit located in front of or behind the ear.
  • It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present from birth.
  • These pits can sometimes become infected, leading to symptoms like pain, swelling, and discharge.
  • Surgical removal may be considered if there are recurrent infections or other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having tapping movements and lack of attention. He seems to be irritated, disturbing others, and restless most of the time. What should be the drug to be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylphenidate

 

The boy's symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and restlessness are indicative of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is the first-line treatment for ADHD and is FDA-approved for use in children aged six years and older. It is a stimulant medication that has been found to be more effective in managing ADHD symptoms compared to non-stimulants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atomoxetine: A non-stimulant medication also used to treat ADHD but generally considered when stimulants are not effective or cause intolerable side effects.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Another non-stimulant medication for ADHD, typically used as an adjunctive treatment or when stimulants are not suitable.

 

Option D. Clozapine: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and not indicated for ADHD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for managing ADHD in children six years and older due to its effectiveness in reducing symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity.

choices.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

 

Lithium doses may need adjustment during pregnancy due to changes in renal clearance, especially in the third trimester, to minimize toxicity risks while maintaining therapeutic effects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose: Increasing the dose isn't recommended due to increased risk of lithium toxicity in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to valproate: Switching to valproate is not advised due to its high teratogenic risk, especially for neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Stop the drug and proceed drug free: Stopping lithium abruptly can lead to a high risk of relapse in bipolar disorder; it's important to manage it carefully.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
Do clerical work and check ECG

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of beta thalassemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, she develops anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion

 

Explanation

 

The development of anxiety, hypotension, and fever during a blood transfusion indicates a possible acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening reaction often due to ABO incompatibility. The immediate and most critical step in managing this reaction is to stop the transfusion immediately.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization: This may be considered in mild allergic reactions with symptoms like urticaria and itching, but not in the presence of hypotension and fever.

 

Option C. Do clerical work and check ECG: These are part of the subsequent steps, but the immediate action is to stop the transfusion.

 

Option D. Administer Hydrocortisone: This may be appropriate for mild allergic reactions but is not the first line of action in suspected severe transfusion reactions.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In any suspected severe transfusion reaction, immediately stop the transfusion to prevent further complications.

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia
Von Willebrand disease type 1

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

 

The symptoms described in the question—acute severe pain episodes in the fingers and toes—are characteristic of vaso-occlusive crises, which are a hallmark of sickle cell anemia. These episodes are caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells that obstruct blood flow in small blood vessels, leading to ischemic pain. This condition results from a mutation leading to the production of hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under low oxygen conditions, distorting the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

 

 

  • HbF, ↑ WBC, LDH is predictive of clinical severity.
  • Target Hb < 10g/dL (To minimize risk of Sickling episodes due to high viscosity).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-thalassemia: This condition involves a deficiency in the production of alpha globin chains but does not typically manifest with acute pain episodes like sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Beta-thalassemia: Like alpha-thalassemia, this involves a problem with globin chain production (beta chains in this case) and also does not typically present with acute pain episodes.

 

Option D. Von Willebrand disease type 1: This is a bleeding disorder, not a hemoglobinopathy, characterized by a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which helps with blood clotting. It would more commonly present with symptoms related to bleeding rather than ischemic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia should be suspected in patients who present with episodic acute pain in the extremities, a symptom commonly resulting from vaso-occlusive crises due to abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

 

Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. In this case, the patient presents with massive splenomegaly, fever, anemia, and other features suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India. The vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania is the Phlebotomus species, commonly known as sandflies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rat fly: Rat flies are not vectors for Leishmania. They are typically associated with the spread of different diseases, like murine typhus, but not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Chrysops fly: Chrysops flies are known as deer flies and are vectors for diseases like Loiasis but are not involved in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Option D. Black fly: Black flies are vectors for Onchocerciasis (river blindness) and have no role in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

 

The presented clinical scenario and X-ray reveal widespread calcification in both kidneys, indicating a condition known as nephrocalcinosis, often associated with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Nephrocalcinosis is characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, and it commonly arises from conditions that lead to elevated calcium levels, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in tissues, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms. It does not typically present with nephrocalcinosis or the specific set of symptoms described, such as muscle weakness and abdominal discomfort related to calcium imbalance.

 

Option B. Addison's disease: This condition involves adrenal insufficiency and can present with fatigue and abdominal pain but is not associated with nephrocalcinosis. It also does not explain the hypercalcemia indicated by kidney calcifications in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to thick mucus secretions and digestive complications. It is not associated with kidney calcifications or the hormonal imbalances of the parathyroid gland as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines McNaughten's rule? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Section 84 of IPC

 

Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind

 

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

 

Other Options

 

Other 3 options are not related to the McNaughten Rule

 

Educational Objective

 

Section 84 of IPC defines the act of a person of unsound mind and is derived from the McNaughten Rule, providing a legal defense for individuals who commit crimes due to their mental incapacity.

questions.text: The first organ to undergo Rigor mortis amongst the following options is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myocardium

 

  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis
  • It first affects the involuntary muscles starting with the myocardium
  • The order of appearance in voluntary muscles is:
    • Upper eyelids
    • Neck muscles,
    • Jaw
    • Facial muscles
    • Chest
    • Upper limbs
    • Abdomen
    • Lower limbs
    • Finger and toes
  • Order of disappearance is also the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Nysten's law, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium (heart muscle) among the listed options.

 

Rigor mortis follows the “rule of 12”- 12 hrs. to set in, remains for 12 hrs., and passes off in 12 hrs.

questions.text: As the member of a school health committee, you are revising the school health program to improve student well-being. Which of the following is NOT a standard component of school health? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Doctor on school premises

 

School health service includes all the above except the presence of a doctor in the school premises.

 

In 1961, ‘Renuka Roy School Health Committee’ laid the foundations for a comprehensive school health programme in India. School health committee (1961) in India recommended medical examination of children ‘at the time of entry and thereafter every 4 years’ [New NRHM guideline: Once every 6 months]. 

 

School health checkup comes under Secondary level of prevention

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teaching handicapped children: This is an essential part of ensuring that all students, including those with disabilities, receive appropriate education and support.

 

Option C. Dental and eye health services: Regular dental and eye check-ups are standard components of school health programs to identify and address common health issues.

 

Option D. School health records: Maintaining health records is crucial for tracking the health and well-being of students over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School Health Program includes:

 

  • Screening of general health assessment of visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up etc.
  • First-aid and emergency care
  • Education of handicapped children
  • Health education
  • Maintenance and use of school health records

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

 

These medications are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Therefore, women who are planning to conceive should discontinue these medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labetalol: Labetalol is generally safe for use during pregnancy and is a treatment option for hypertension in pregnant women. It is not necessary to discontinue this medication.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers like nifedipine are also generally considered safe during pregnancy and are often used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option D. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa is also considered safe during pregnancy and is commonly used for managing hypertension in this population.

 

Given the woman's intention to conceive, discontinuing Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors would be the most appropriate course of action to protect both her health and that of her future child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: PET scan is based on: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose metabolism

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans are primarily based on glucose metabolism. The radiopharmaceutical used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which is an analog of glucose. This radiotracer is preferentially taken up by cells that have a high rate of glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect explains this phenomenon, where cancer cells consume glucose at much higher rates than normal cells, making them visible on PET scans due to the concentration of 18F-FDG.

 

Once 18F-FDG is inside the cell, it undergoes phosphorylation but does not proceed through the full glycolytic pathway, leading to its trapping within the cell. The emitted positrons from fluorine-18 collide with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays, which are detected by the PET scanner to create an image showing areas of high glucose metabolism.

 

Other 3 Options are incorrect, not the basis for PET scan.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

PET scans are based on glucose metabolism, utilizing 18F-FDG to detect areas of high metabolic activity, particularly in cancer cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain. Further workup showed elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which investigation should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tc-99m sestamibi scan

 

The patient presents with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and renal calculi, which are indicative of hypercalcemia. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a parathyroid adenoma. In this scenario, the appropriate next step in investigation is a Tc-99m sestamibi scan, which is the investigation of choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

A Tc-99m sestamibi scan is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that is specifically useful for locating parathyroid adenomas. It helps in identifying hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue by using a radiotracer that is absorbed more by the adenomatous parathyroid gland compared to normal tissue.

 

Note –

 

Better answer - Sestamibi SPECT >> Tc-99m sestamibi scan

 

While, Technetium 99m Sestamibi typically offers a 2D representation similar to an X-ray, Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) combines the use of Technetium 99m Sestamibi with CT to create three-dimensional images (used gamma rays). Sestamibi SPECT provides a more detailed and accurate localization of parathyroid adenomas. This can be crucial for surgical planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioactive iodine uptake test: This test is used primarily in the evaluation of thyroid function, particularly in cases of hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant in the evaluation of parathyroid adenomas or primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Dexa scan: A Dexa scan is used to measure bone mineral density, typically to assess the risk of osteoporosis. While hyperparathyroidism can lead to decreased bone density, the Dexa scan is not the investigation of choice to identify the cause of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. USG thyroid: Ultrasound of the thyroid can be used to visualize the thyroid gland and detect nodules or other abnormalities. However, it is not as sensitive as Tc-99m sestamibi scan for identifying parathyroid adenomas, particularly when they are small or located in ectopic positions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with elevated PTH levels and clinical features suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, such as renal calculi, the Tc-99m sestamibi scan is the preferred investigation to localize a parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

The patient's presentation includes a constellation of symptoms and laboratory findings indicative of Legionella pneumonia, also known as Legionnaires' disease. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • High-grade fever, cough, and confusion: Common symptoms of Legionella pneumonia.
  • Diarrhea: Gastrointestinal manifestations are frequently associated with Legionella infections.
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray: Legionella pneumonia typically presents with infiltrates rather than consolidation.
  • Hyponatremia (Na: 126 mEq/L): Commonly seen in Legionella due to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).
  • Elevated liver enzymes (AST: 62, ALT: 56): Transaminitis is often observed in Legionella infections.
  • Normal bilirubin and random blood sugar levels: These findings are not specific but do not rule out Legionella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus: Streptococcal pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and does not commonly cause significant gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: This organism typically affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) and presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than focal infiltrates and lacks gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option D. Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and "currant jelly" sputum. It does not typically cause gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Testis

 

Radiosensitivity refers to the susceptibility of tissues or cells to the harmful effects of radiation. The testis, particularly the germ cells within the testis, are highly radiosensitive because they have a high rate of cell division and less differentiation. Gonads, in general, are among the most radiosensitive tissues in the body. This is why testis is the correct answer.

 

Although bone is mentioned, it is not specified whether it refers to bone marrow or bone tissue. Bone marrow is indeed highly radiosensitive, but when only "bone" is mentioned, it generally refers to the harder, more resistant bone tissue rather than the marrow. Hence, in the presence of the option "testis," which is clearly highly radiosensitive, the testis is the more appropriate choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle: Muscle tissues are relatively radioresistant because they consist of mature, differentiated cells that do not divide frequently.

 

Option B. Nerve: Nerve cells are also radioresistant due to their low mitotic activity and high differentiation, making them less susceptible to radiation damage.

 

Option C. Bone: As explained, "bone" generally refers to the solid bone tissue, which is not as radiosensitive as bone marrow. The ambiguity in the term "bone" makes it a less clear choice compared to "testis."

 

Educational Objective:

 

The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

     

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation is a safety feature designed to release pressure when it exceeds a certain limit to prevent barotrauma to the patient. This valve typically releases at a pressure range of 30-40 cm of water (H2O). This pressure setting helps ensure that the air is delivered to the patient safely without causing excessive force that could damage the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

choices.text: Mandatory episiotomy
Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver
Deliver in lithotomy position only

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses


The WHO guidelines for managing the second stage of labor emphasize techniques to reduce perineal trauma and enhance maternal comfort. The use of manual perineal support and warm compresses is recommended to protect the perineum during delivery and reduce the incidence of severe perineal tears.

 

  • Manual Perineal Support and Warm Compresses:
    • Manual Support: Hands-on guarding of the perineum during delivery helps control the speed of delivery and reduces the risk of severe perineal tears.
    • Warm Compresses: Applying warm compresses to the perineum can help relax the tissues and make them more pliable, further reducing the risk of tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandatory Episiotomy: Not Recommended: Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended by the WHO. It is only indicated in specific cases where it is necessary to expedite delivery for the safety of the mother or baby.

 

Option C. Maintain Head in Deflexion and Deliver: Not Recommended: The recommendation is to allow the fetal head to assume the most optimal position for delivery rather than intentionally maintaining deflexion, which may hinder the delivery process.

 

Option D. Deliver in Lithotomy Position Only: Not Recommended: The WHO supports a variety of birthing positions based on the mother’s preference and comfort. Restricting delivery to the lithotomy position is not recommended; instead, women should be encouraged to choose their preferred position.

 

Educational Objective:


Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient of fish odor syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choline

 

Choline should be avoided by patients with fish odor syndrome. Choline is metabolized in the body to trimethylamine (TMA), which is responsible for the fishy odor in individuals with TMAU. Therefore, reducing choline intake can help manage the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin is not typically associated with exacerbating fish odor syndrome, so it does not need to be avoided.

 

Option C. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is not directly related to fish odor syndrome. It does not need to be avoided.

 

Option D. Pantothenic Acid: Pantothenic acid, also known as vitamin B5, is not directly associated with fish odor syndrome and does not need to be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is a metabolic syndrome caused by abnormal excretion of trimethylamine in the breath, urine, sweat, saliva and vaginal secretions. Trimethylamine is derived from the intestinal bacterial degradation of foods rich in choline and carnitine and is normally oxidized by the liver to odorless trimethylamine N-oxide which is then excreted in the urine. Impaired oxidation of trimethylamine due to the deficiency of flavin containing mono oxygenase 3 (FMO3) is thought to be the cause of the fish odor syndrome and is responsible for the smell of rotting fish.

 

Foods like eggs, liver, peanuts, meat, poultry, fish, dairy foods, pasta and rice are to be avoided.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PET CT

 

The above imaging modality is a PET CT scan.

 

  • PET scan: Positron emission tomography
  • 18-FDG: 18F is combined with deoxy glucose (ligand)
  • To look for malignant cells
  • Functional metabolism

 

Warburg Effect: Malignant cells → anaerobic glycolysis

 

 

  • Concept: Coincidence – Annihilation reaction
  • Prerequisite before performing PET scan: Blood glucose measurement

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Cerebral blood flow scan: Typically involves methods like SPECT or perfusion MRI to measure blood flow in the brain.

 

 

Option. C. Sestamibi scan: Generally used for myocardial perfusion imaging or parathyroid imaging, involving a different radiotracer.

 

 

Option. D. Full body MDCT (Multi-detector computed tomography): Provides high-resolution anatomical information across the whole body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A PET CT scan is crucial for the integrated assessment of anatomical and metabolic information, particularly useful in oncology for identifying and tracking the behavior of tumors based on their glucose metabolism, as visualized through radiotracer uptake.

questions.text: A 6-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent projectile vomiting. USG of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 

The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is commonly seen in infants, particularly around 6 weeks of age, and is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to the thickening of the pyloric muscle, which leads to gastric outlet obstruction. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis, showing a thickened hypoechoic pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal, confirming the presence of CHPS. Key diagnostic measurements on ultrasound include pyloric muscle thickness greater than 4 mm and canal length greater than 16 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Typically presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with the “double bubble” sign on X-ray, not ultrasound. It does not present with projectile vomiting.

 

Option B. Jejunal atresia: Presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with a “triple bubble” sign on imaging studies, typically on X-ray. This condition does not match the clinical presentation or the ultrasound findings shown in the question.

 

Option D. Midgut volvulus: This condition presents with bilious vomiting and can show a corkscrew sign on contrast imaging studies due to the twisting of the bowel on its own axis. It is diagnosed using contrast imaging, not ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant around 6 weeks of age, and is best diagnosed with an ultrasound showing thickened pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal.

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine

 

Carnitine plays a crucial role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane for subsequent beta-oxidation. It forms a complex with fatty acids, allowing them to enter the mitochondria.

 

Fatty acid transport into mitochondria from cytoplasm involve the carnitine shuttle system using enzymes Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) and CPT-II. CPT-I is RLE of fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation of fatty acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyl carrier protein: Acyl carrier proteins are involved in fatty acid synthesis rather than transport across the mitochondrial membrane. They are essential components of fatty acid biosynthesis pathways.

 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: Cholesterol transporters primarily facilitate the transport of cholesterol, not fatty acids, across cellular membranes. They are not directly involved in fatty acid transport into mitochondria.

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT is an enzyme responsible for esterifying cholesterol, and it does not play a role in fatty acid transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.

 

Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

 

The patient has a history of tuberculosis and now presents with hemoptysis. The chest X-ray shows a cavity with a mass inside it, which is suggestive of an aspergilloma, also known as a fungal ball.

 

Aspergilloma typically forms in pre-existing lung cavities caused by conditions such as tuberculosis. The fungal ball is composed of Aspergillus organisms and debris, and it often presents as a crescent-shaped shadow known as Monod's sign, although this may not always be clearly visible.

 

Most patients with aspergilloma are asymptomatic, but when symptoms do occur, hemoptysis is the most common presenting symptom, ranging from mild to life-threatening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer: While bronchogenic cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, can present with cavitating lesions, it is less likely in this case given the patient's history of TB and the appearance of the cavity with a mass, which is more typical of aspergilloma.

 

Option C. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses also present as cavitating lesions, but they typically show air-fluid levels on imaging, which are not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic cyst: Bronchogenic cysts have a completely different radiographic appearance and clinical presentation. They are typically congenital and do not present as cavitating lesions with a mass inside them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
